headline.main: Why Smoking Rates Are at New Lows

docs.abstract: The smoking rate among adults in the United States has dropped again, an encouraging trend that experts on smoking cessation attribute to public policies like smoke-free air laws and cigarette taxes.
docs.snippet: The smoking rate among adults in the United States has dropped again, an encouraging trend that experts on smoking cessation attribute to public policies like smoke-free air laws and cigarette taxes.

headline.print_headline: Clinic Races to Adapt to Health Care Overhaul
headline.main: A Louisville Clinic Races to Adapt to the Health Care Overhaul

docs.abstract: Medical clinics across country are racing to adapt to health care overhaul by January 2014, when Affordable Care Act will require most Americans to have health insurance; New York Times investigation will look periodically at its impact in Louisville, Ky, city of 60,000 that embodies both triumphs and shortcomings of the medical system in United States (Series: Remaking Medicine).

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: To follow how the health care overhaul is playing out, The Times will look periodically at its impact in Louisville, Ky., a city that embodies the triumphs and the shortcomings of the medical system.
docs.snippet: To follow how the health care overhaul is playing out, The Times will look periodically at its impact in Louisville, Ky., a city that embodies the triumphs and the shortcomings of the medical system.

headline.seo: ‘The Anatomy of Violence,’ by Adrian Raine

docs.abstract: Paul Bloom reviews book The Anatomy of Violence: The Biological Roots of Crime by Adrian Raine.
docs.lead_paragraph: A criminologist examines the biological roots of violence, and argues that “the seeds of sin are brain-based.”
docs.snippet: A criminologist examines the biological roots of violence, and argues that “the seeds of sin are brain-based.”
